elements.content: A lanthanide-based metal organic framework, formulated Tb(C27H15O6)(H2O)·2C6H11OH, has been solvothermally synthesized using the extended rigid tritopic ligand 1,3,5-tribenzoate. Included free solvent could be removed upon heating, and the resulting material presents large 1-D micropores (free diameter = 10 Å) and a high surface area (S Langmuir > 1000 m2·g-1).
elements.clean_text: A lanthanide-based metal organic framework, formulated Tb(C27H15O6)(H2O)⋅2C6H11OH, has been solvothermally synthesized using the extended rigid tritopic ligand 1,3,5-tribenzoate. Included free solvent could be removed upon heating, and the resulting material presents large 1-D micropores (free diameter = 10 Å) and a high surface area (S Langmuir > 1000 m2⋅g-1).

elements.content: Among the porous polycarboxylate-based metal organic frameworks (MOFs), those based on rare-earth cations have deserved a special attention due to their ability to form multifunctional hybrid materials, combining their intrinsic porous character with physical properties coming from the rare-earth, in the field of magnetism, catalysis, or luminescence. Many lanthanide-based MOFs present relatively open frameworks with included solvent molecules, but collapse or become amorphous under guest removal, even if they present reversible solvent exchange. However, a few solids remain crystallized5a,h,6 upon solvent departure and present a permanent porosity, but to our knowledge, only one lanthanide carboxylate (Tb(BTC)(H2O)1.5·(DMF), MOF-76) has been proven to show a significant porosity relative to nitrogen.
elements.clean_text: Among the porous polycarboxylate-based metal organic frameworks (MOFs), those based on rare-earth cations have deserved a special attention due to their ability to form multifunctional hybrid materials, combining their intrinsic porous character with physical properties coming from the rare-earth, in the field of magnetism, catalysis, or luminescence. Many lanthanide-based MOFs present relatively open frameworks with included solvent molecules, but collapse or become amorphous under guest removal, even if they present reversible solvent exchange. However, a few solids remain crystallized5a,h,6 upon solvent departure and present a permanent porosity, but to our knowledge, only one lanthanide carboxylate (Tb(BTC)(H2O)1.5⋅(DMF), MOF-76) has been proven to show a significant porosity relative to nitrogen.

elements.content: We present here the synthesis, crystal structure, and nitrogen sorption properties of Tb(BTB)(H2O)·2(C6H12O) (BTB = 1,3,5-benzenetrisbenzoate), a three-dimensional lanthanide carboxylate MOF, later denoted MIL-103, presenting a permanent porosity and a high surface area after guest removal.
elements.clean_text: We present here the synthesis, crystal structure, and nitrogen sorption properties of Tb(BTB)(H2O)⋅2(C6H12O) (BTB = 1,3,5-benzenetrisbenzoate), a three-dimensional lanthanide carboxylate MOF, later denoted MIL-103, presenting a permanent porosity and a high surface area after guest removal.

elements.content: The BTB ligand, already used by Yaghi and co-workers with transition-metal cations to produce highly porous MOFs, was synthesized starting from 1,3,5-tritolylbenzene10 following the published procedure. MIL-103 was hydrothermally synthesized from stoichiometric amounts of TbCl3·6H2O, H3BTB, and NaOH in a 1:1 biphasic mixture of water and cyclohexanol12 (see Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: The BTB ligand, already used by Yaghi and co-workers with transition-metal cations to produce highly porous MOFs, was synthesized starting from 1,3,5-tritolylbenzene10 following the published procedure. MIL-103 was hydrothermally synthesized from stoichiometric amounts of TbCl3⋅6H2O, H3BTB, and NaOH in a 1:1 biphasic mixture of water and cyclohexanol12 (see Supporting Information).

elements.content: MIL-103 is trigonal (a = 28.5344(8) Å, c = 12.2148(5) Å, space group R32), and the structure is a rare case of the (3,5)-coordinated minimal net hms. TbIII ions are 9-fold coordinated by eight carboxylate oxygen atoms and one water molecule, in accordance with bond valence calculations (v Tb = 2.91−3.18, v Ow = 0.33−0.36, depending on the bond valence parameters used15). Edge-sharing [TbO9] polyhedra define chains running in the c direction. They are connected by the extended tritopic BTB3- ligand to afford 1-D hexagonal pores containing the free cyclohexanol molecules (Figure ). When solvent is removed, free cylinders of ca. 10 Å diameter (taking into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms) are defined (see Figure ).
elements.clean_text: MIL-103 is trigonal (a = 28.5344(8) Å, c = 12.2148(5) Å, space group R32), and the structure is a rare case of the (3,5)-coordinated minimal net hms. TbIII ions are 9-fold coordinated by eight carboxylate oxygen atoms and one water molecule, in accordance with bond valence calculations (v Tb = 2.91-3.18, v Ow = 0.33-0.36, depending on the bond valence parameters used15). Edge-sharing [TbO9] polyhedra define chains running in the c direction. They are connected by the extended tritopic BTB3- ligand to afford 1-D hexagonal pores containing the free cyclohexanol molecules (Figure ). When solvent is removed, free cylinders of ca. 10 Å diameter (taking into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms) are defined (see Figure ).

elements.content: View of MIL-103 along thec axis, showing the hexagonal pores filled with free solvent molecules (one pore is pictured empty for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  View of MIL-103 along thec axis, showing the hexagonal pores filled with free solvent molecules (one pore is pictured empty for clarity).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis was performed under oxygen atmosphere (see insert in Figure ). A 23% weight loss is observed between room temperature and 150 °C, which is consistent with the free solvent departure (theoretical 24−25%). A slightly decreasing plateau follows (2% weight loss, which could be associated with the coordinated water departure) until 400 °C, where MIL-103 collapses. The remaining product is Tb2O3, with a residual mass (77% weight loss) consistent with theoretical value (77%).

A slightly decreasing plateau follows (2% weight loss, which could be associated with the coordinated water departure) until 400 °C, where MIL-103 collapses. The remaining product is Tb2O3, with a residual mass (77% weight loss) consistent with theoretical value (77%).

elements.content: X-ray thermodiffractogram of MIL-103 under air from 20 to 500 °C. The following color code corresponding to the structural changes (see text) was used:  red (20−90 °C), blue (100−260 °C), green (280−400 °C), purple (420−500 °C). Insert:  TG analysis under oxygen (1 °C/min).
elements.clean_text: 2  X-ray thermodiffractogram of MIL-103 under air from 20 to 500 °C. The following color code corresponding to the structural changes (see text) was used: red (20-90 °C), blue (100-260 °C), green (280-400 °C), purple (420-500 °C). Insert: TG analysis under oxygen (1 °C/min).

elements.content: X-ray thermodiffraction analysis was carried under air. Noticeable diffraction intensity variations are observed between 50 and 100 °C, accompanied by a slight position shift of the Bragg peaks. No change occurs until 280 °C, where the long-range order begins to disappear to form an amorphous phase above 420 °C (Figure ) before apparition of Tb2O3 upon further heating.
elements.clean_text: X-ray thermodiffraction analysis was carried under air. Noticeable diffraction intensity variations are observed between 50 and 100 °C, accompanied by a slight position shift of the Bragg peaks. No change occurs until 280 °C, where the long-range order begins to disappear to form an amorphous phase above 420 °C (Figure ) before apparition of Tb2O3 upon further heating.

elements.content: The first change certainly corresponds to a small structural rearrangement consecutive to the solvent departure (cell indexing at 220 °C:  a = 28.178(1) Å, c = 12.196(1) Å). The loss of crystallinity above 280 °C could be associated with the bound water departure, which is consistent with the TG analysis. MIL-103 heated at 300 °C does not recover its crystallinity after rehydration, proving that the transformation is irreversible on the day time scale.
elements.clean_text: The first change certainly corresponds to a small structural rearrangement consecutive to the solvent departure (cell indexing at 220 °C: a = 28.178(1) Å, c = 12.196(1) Å). The loss of crystallinity above 280 °C could be associated with the bound water departure, which is consistent with the TG analysis. MIL-103 heated at 300 °C does not recover its crystallinity after rehydration, proving that the transformation is irreversible on the day time scale.

elements.content: The nitrogen sorption properties of MIL-103 were investigated. The as-synthesized product was degassed at 150 °C for 15 h under vacuum, and the sorption measurement was performed at 77 K using nitrogen as the sorbed gas. As shown in Figure , MIL-103 exhibits a typical type I isotherm, with a Langmuir surface area greater than 1000 m2·g-1 (ranging from 1030 to 1330 m2·g-1, depending on the batch used; surfaces between 730 and 930 m2·g-1 were found using the BET model). The same experiment performed after activation at 300 °C gives a surface of 60 m2·g-1, confirming that the loss of crystallinity above 280 °C corresponds to the collapse of the structure.
elements.clean_text: The nitrogen sorption properties of MIL-103 were investigated. The as-synthesized product was degassed at 150 °C for 15 h under  vacuum, and the sorption measurement was performed at 77 K using nitrogen as the sorbed gas. As shown in Figure , MIL-103 exhibits a typical type I isotherm, with a Langmuir surface area greater than 1000 m2⋅g-1 (ranging from 1030 to 1330 m2⋅g-1, depending on the batch used; surfaces between 730 and 930 m2⋅g-1 were found using the BET model). The same experiment performed after activation at 300 °C gives a surface of 60 m2⋅g-1, confirming that the loss of crystallinity above 280 °C corresponds to the collapse of the structure.

elements.content: Nitrogen gas adsorption isotherm at 77 K for MIL-103 degassed overnight at 150 °C.P/P 0 is the ratio of gas pressure (P) to saturation pressure (P 0 = 750 mmHg). V is the adsorbed volume.
elements.clean_text: 3  Nitrogen gas adsorption isotherm at 77 K for MIL-103 degassed overnight at 150 °C.P/P 0 is the ratio of gas pressure (P) to saturation pressure (P 0 = 750 mmHg). V is the adsorbed volume.

elements.content:
This is so far the largest surface area reported for lanthanide-based porous solids, far beyond the best one previously reported for rare-earth-based MOF (S Langmuir = 334 m2·g-1 for MOF-76).

MIL-103 could also be synthesized with other light rare-earth elements (RE = Y, La−Ho). Moreover, in the H3BTB/REIIIX3 (X = Cl, NO3) system, only this single crystalline phase was observed up to now, as checked by powder diffraction, whatever the temperature (100−200 °C), reaction time (10 h to 9 days), NaOH/H3BTB/LnX3 ratio, and concentrations were used.
elements.clean_text:
This is so far the largest surface area reported for lanthanide-based porous solids, far beyond the best one previously reported for rare-earth-based MOF (S Langmuir = 334 m2⋅g-1 for MOF-76). 

MIL-103 could also be synthesized with other light rare-earth elements (RE = Y, La-Ho). Moreover, in the H3BTB/REIIIX3 (X = Cl, NO3) system, only this single crystalline phase was observed up to now, as checked by powder diffraction, whatever the temperature (100-200 °C), reaction time (10 h to 9 days), NaOH/H3BTB/LnX3 ratio, and concentrations were used.

elements.content: To conclude, we present here the first lanthanide-based MOF keeping its crystalline order upon guest removal and showing both large pores (free diameter >10 Å) and a high surface area (>1000 m2·g-1) relative to nitrogen. Studies of the lability of the bound water by solid-state NMR, which is of importance for catalytic applications, as well as luminescence measurements and insertion properties are in progress and will be reported in due course.

Studies of the lability of the bound water by solid-state NMR, which is of importance for catalytic applications, as well as luminescence measurements and insertion properties are in progress and will be reported in due course.

elements.content: Full synthetic method, IR spectra and CIF file for MIL-103(Tb), powder diffraction data for MIL-103(RE) (RE = Y, La−Ho). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

Supporting Information Available 

Full synthetic method, IR spectra and CIF file for MIL-103(Tb), powder diffraction data for MIL-103(RE) (RE = Y, La-Ho). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
A lanthanide-based metal organic framework, formulated Tb(C27H15O6)(H2O)·2C6H11OH, has been solvothermally synthesized using the extended rigid tritopic ligand 1,3,5-tribenzoate. Included free solvent could be removed upon heating, and the resulting material presents large 1-D micropores (free diameter = 10 Å) and a high surface area (S Langmuir > 1000 m2·g-1).

Thermogravimetric analysis was performed under oxygen atmosphere (see insert in Figure ). A 23% weight loss is observed between room temperature and 150 °C, which is consistent with the free solvent departure (theoretical 24−25%). A slightly decreasing plateau follows (2% weight loss, which could be associated with the coordinated water departure) until 400 °C, where MIL-103 collapses. The remaining product is Tb2O3, with a residual mass (77% weight loss) consistent with theoretical value (77%).

The nitrogen sorption properties of MIL-103 were investigated. The as-synthesized product was degassed at 150 °C for 15 h under vacuum, and the sorption measurement was performed at 77 K using nitrogen as the sorbed gas. As shown in Figure , MIL-103 exhibits a typical type I isotherm, with a Langmuir surface area greater than 1000 m2·g-1 (ranging from 1030 to 1330 m2·g-1, depending on the batch used; surfaces between 730 and 930 m2·g-1 were found using the BET model). The same experiment performed after activation at 300 °C gives a surface of 60 m2·g-1, confirming that the loss of crystallinity above 280 °C corresponds to the collapse of the structure.

To conclude, we present here the first lanthanide-based MOF keeping its crystalline order upon guest removal and showing both large pores (free diameter >10 Å) and a high surface area (>1000 m2·g-1) relative to nitrogen. Studies of the lability of the bound water by solid-state NMR, which is of importance for catalytic applications, as well as luminescence measurements and insertion properties are in progress and will be reported in due course.
cln_elements.clean_text:
A lanthanide-based metal organic framework, formulated Tb(C27H15O6)(H2O)⋅2C6H11OH, has been solvothermally synthesized using the extended rigid tritopic ligand 1,3,5-tribenzoate. Included free solvent could be removed upon heating, and the resulting material presents large 1-D micropores (free diameter = 10 Å) and a high surface area (S Langmuir > 1000 m2⋅g-1). 

Thermogravimetric analysis was performed under oxygen atmosphere (see insert in Figure ). A 23% weight loss is observed between room temperature and 150 °C, which is consistent with the free solvent departure (theoretical 24-25%). A slightly decreasing plateau follows (2% weight loss, which could be associated with the coordinated water departure) until 400 °C, where MIL-103 collapses. The remaining product is Tb2O3, with a residual mass (77% weight loss) consistent with theoretical value (77%).  

The nitrogen sorption properties of MIL-103 were investigated. The as-synthesized product was degassed at 150 °C for 15 h under  vacuum, and the sorption measurement was performed at 77 K using nitrogen as the sorbed gas. As shown in Figure , MIL-103 exhibits a typical type I isotherm, with a Langmuir surface area greater than 1000 m2⋅g-1 (ranging from 1030 to 1330 m2⋅g-1, depending on the batch used; surfaces between 730 and 930 m2⋅g-1 were found using the BET model). The same experiment performed after activation at 300 °C gives a surface of 60 m2⋅g-1, confirming that the loss of crystallinity above 280 °C corresponds to the collapse of the structure.  

To conclude, we present here the first lanthanide-based MOF keeping its crystalline order upon guest removal and showing both large pores (free diameter >10 Å) and a high surface area (>1000 m2⋅g-1) relative to nitrogen. Studies of the lability of the bound water by solid-state NMR, which is of importance for catalytic applications, as well as luminescence measurements and insertion properties are in progress and will be reported in due course.

metadata.title:
MIL-103, A 3-D Lanthanide-Based Metal Organic Framework with Large
One-Dimensional Tunnels and A High Surface Area
